title: Working with Notebooks
text:
Code
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

r = np.arange(0, 4, 0.01)
theta = 2 * np.pi * r
fig, ax = plt.subplots(
  subplot_kw = {'projection': 'polar'} 
)
ax.plot(theta, r)
ax.set_rticks([0.5, 1, 1.5, 2])
ax.grid(True)
plt.show()





Figure 1: A line plot on a polar axis





Develop a notebook
Render that notebook via
(quarto_env) user@hostname:~/...$ quarto render notebook_name.ipynb
Preview your document via
(quarto_env) user@hostname:~/...$ quarto preview quarto_blog/
Note: Make sure draft: false in your document, or it won’t render.

title: About
text:
Matt Triano is a Data Scientist at the University of Chicago’s Urban Labs. When not innovating on data platforms, Matt enjoys exploring new tech, open source development, and hardware hacking.
